glossary.primary_meaning: To board or climb onto something, or to progress or manage a situation successfully.

table.meaning: To board or climb onto a vehicle or surface.
table.context: She managed to get on the train just in time before the doors closed.

table.meaning: To manage or progress successfully in a situation.
table.context: He’s getting on well with his new project at work.

multiple_choice.question: What does 'get on' mean in this sentence: 'I need to get on the bus before it leaves.'?
Choose the correct meaning of 'get on': 'She’s getting on well with her studies.'

word_choice.sentence: She managed to ___ / ___ the plane just before takeoff.
He’s trying to ___ / ___ with his new responsibilities.

content.short_story: Lisa was running late for work. She rushed to the station and managed to get on the train at the last second. At her office, she was determined to get on with her new tasks, eager to impress her boss. Despite a hectic start, she felt she was getting on well with her colleagues. By the end of the day, Lisa felt a sense of accomplishment as she headed home.
movie_examples: "Hurry up, get on the bus before it leaves!" - Speed (1994)
"I’ll get on with the mission, no matter the risks." - Mission: Impossible (1996)
"We’ve got to get on that plane right now!" - Casablanca (1942)
song_examples: "Get on your feet, get up and make it happen." - Song by Gloria Estefan
"Get on the bus, don’t be late." - Song by Destiny’s Child
"Get on the dance floor and show me what you got." - Song by Snap!

glossary.primary_meaning: To place something on a surface, body, or other object, or to assume a certain behavior or role.

table.meaning: To wear or apply clothing, accessories, or makeup.
table.context: She put on her coat before leaving the house.

table.meaning: To turn on or start an appliance or device.
table.context: He put on the TV to watch the news.

table.meaning: To assume a particular behavior, attitude, or role.
table.context: He put on a brave face despite being nervous.

multiple_choice.question: What does 'put on' mean in this sentence: 'I need to put on a sweater; it’s cold outside.'?
Choose the correct meaning of 'put on': 'She put on her makeup before the party.'

word_choice.sentence: Before the meeting, he decided to ___ / ___ a tie.
Can you ___ / ___ the radio? I’d like to hear the news.

content.short_story: Sarah woke up feeling groggy. She put on her favorite slippers and shuffled to the kitchen. After breakfast, she put on the radio to listen to her morning show. Later, she put on a big smile as she greeted her boss, masking her tiredness. By evening, Sarah felt relieved as she put on a cozy sweater and settled in to relax.
movie_examples: "Put on your seatbelt before we start driving!" - Fast & Furious (2001)
"Don’t forget to put on your sunscreen." - The Parent Trap (1998)
"She put on her best performance of the season." - Black Swan (2010)
song_examples: "Put on your red shoes and dance the blues." - Song by David Bowie
"Put on a happy face, let the sunshine in." - Song by Tony Bennett
"Put on your Sunday best; we’re going out tonight." - Song by Lionel Richie
